title: What will be the 12-month percentage change in the US Consumer Price Index (CPI) for September 2021?
preds: For the month of August, the 12-month CPI % increase was 5.3% (https://www.bls.gov/cpi/). In July, this number was at 5.4% (https://www.bls.gov/news.release/cpi.nr0.htm). For the 12-month CPI percent change to dip below 3.1% for September, we would need to see severe deflation, likely caused by COVID-19 or a remarkable market crash. However, COVID-19 recovery has continued and government spending seems set to increase, assuming that some form of the proposed multi-trillion dollar infrastructure bill is passed (https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/09/30/us/government-shutdown-infrastructure). Therefore, it seems incredibly unlikely (although not impossible) that such a sharp decrease in CPI would occur in such a short amount of time.
I think that the CPI will be higher than 3.1% because the percent change in August was 5.3%. I think following this standard, the CPI will not fall below 3.1%

CPI is the most widely used measure of the inflation rate. As the Federal Reserve continues to print more money to support the economy after its catastrophic downturn in 2020, the inflation rate will continue to increase. M1 money supply grew from 4.7 billion in April 2020 to almost 20 billion in August 2021. This indicates absurdly high inflation, which translates to a much higher CPI. A higher CPI is great to keep business afloat but obviously poor for consumers. As long as the government prints more money to pump up the economy and prevent collapse, CPI will grow in turn. As of right now, CPI is currently well above 3.1%, sitting around 5.3% in August. For CPI to become lower than 3.1% would mean an immense economic collapse or shut down which is unforeseen at this point.  https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/h6/current/default.htm
https://www.bls.gov/news.release/cpi.nr0.htm
Currently, the percentage change is well above 3.1%, and it would take some sort of cataclysmic economic collapse happening in the next 24 hours to change that.
For bucket b4 to actualize, the MoM for September needs to be around negative 1.8%. Looking through instances of MoM, negative values are rare enough to warrant  a low probability ~ 1%.
Have not seen any obvious information to suggest lowering my forecast probability so far.

It seems to me that, for the purpose of answering this  question, roughly speaking, CPI for all consumers ~ CPI for urban consumers.  Here is what I see (Urban)         2020                    2021
Jul    258.6                   272.3
Sep  260.1 Jul 2021 vs Jul 2020 is 5.3% which compares well with the official CPI increase of 5.4%. So for Sep 2021 YoY to be less than 3.1%, we need to see negative MoM for Aug & Sep 2021.
My prediction that the supply chain bottlenecks would ease failed to materialize. I am throwing in the towel.
base-effects mean very unlikely to drop below 3% in september unless delta foreces a march 2020 style lockdown which is unlikely given vaccine efficacy
So far, results still elevated (5+).  Leaving forecast the same for now.
updating based on latest report, we're still above 5% with nothing to suggest a sudden drop of more than 2 percentage points.

Not seeing the increasing trend to reverse in the time context of the question (https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2021/08/06/feds-ultraloose-monetary-policy-could-hurt-both-economy-bidens-agenda/)

- https://www.bls.gov/news.release/cpi.nr0.htm
- https://twitter.com/WhiteHouseCEA/status/1392484719212781571
- German inflation just hit 3.8% - that's a new record since 1996. I'm assuming the US one to be similar or higher (due to stimulus checks). https://www.faz.net/aktuell/finanzen/inflation-in-deutschland-steigt-auf-3-8-prozent-17459791.html

Leaving forecast unchanged for now.  At this point it appears very unlikely that the CPI will decrease below the 3.1% level before the competition ends.  Will obviously modify forecast if (as is so typical) I am wrong.

June 2-year CPI change, annualized: 3.00% Still accelerating, per my previous forecast, which means even without base effects (the bulk of which are from earlier in 2020 anyway) we should continue to see high prints.
There is considerable inflation already baked in. This won’t turn around quickly. It’s all but certain to exceed 3.1%.

Used auto prices are down as measured by the Manheim auction. Other indicators are trending lower.
Counter argument in the WSJ this week money supply will push inflation higher by the end of the year - https://www.wsj.com/articles/money-supply-inflation-friedman-biden-federal-reserve-11626816746?mod=searchresults_pos4&page=1
Rate of inflation growth has decreased, we are possibly at peak, and I'm increasingly doubtful that even if we see a decline, it won't be fast enough to get below 3.1%
All in now.  Even the Fed is talking about "transient" inflation lasting into next year.
June 2021 CPI is 5.4% YoY. Given that 3/4 of the monthly CPI's that will be included in the challenge figure have already been printed, I'd say this is a (statistical) certainty at this point.

Raw change in CPI since September is 4.1%. You would need 1% non-annualized, non-seasonally adjusted DEFLATION over the summer for the sept annual rate not to be 3.1%. Not going to happen https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPIAUCSL

Actually going all in on over 3.1%, would have to see inflation decrease by 0.3% or more each month on average over the next three months to land under 3.1%. Still possible we see a month or two of a decline, but overall seems like a negligible chance it drops enough to fall under 3.1%.
+3 on over 3.1, latest number is still high, no signs of it coming back down yet.
We're talking about the inflation 6 months from now. I don't know that it will still be as high as it is today.
Nothing to indicate that inflation is abating now. Best guess is 3.6, which is considerably above 3.1.
Pushing bets toward the upper end

Looking at the data again. We're already at 3.2%, and I don't picture prices going down sufficiently for enough things to get this forecast to 3.1% or lower. Inflation for many items is still expected. I'll reassess when June data come out.
I 100% believe inflation will end up in bin 5, but I only 93% believe I'll be right.
Passage time, and no sign of inflation abating in the short term. My best guess is 3.6 right now.
the last time inflation was this high, four months later it was 1.1%. four months from now is September.
Public Expectations seem more baked in over recent weeks, reflecting fundamental supply chain and resource shortage factors. Fed remains in a mostly dovish slant over next few quarters
The base adjustment will lower the number to 3.74%. Many commodities are falling rapidly, I believe this will feed through to the CPI and the number will be below 3.1%
Adjusting up a bit assuming a) the uptick in CPI will extend at least through Oct 1, and b) that this is more than just a base effect comparison to last year's numbers

Revising upwards. Until about April, it seemed plausible that the higher CPI prints we were seeing were the result of so-called "base effects" (i.e. the CPI looks high because the comparator, last year's prices, fell from about March-August). I realized I could somewhat remove these base effects by looking at 2-year CPI percentage changes (annualized, of course) from https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPIAUCSL. From this, I get
January:  1.92
February:  1.99
March:  2.07
April:  2.23
May:  2.55 In other words, even after somewhat removing base effects, we see a clear upwards trend that is actually in its acceleration phase.  In the scenario that inflation stabilizes at 2.55 for the next few months (the last estimate), I'd expect September's print to be around 3.7.
In the scenario that inflation continues to accelerate and say, hits 3.5 by September, the equivalent print would be about 5.63! Are there scenarios in which we would see deflation? Not many are in that camp, though I think there's still a few voices.
Disinflation is definitely plausible, though unclear on what time horizon. With extra unemployment benefits being phased out, and assuming no more stimulus checks, and supply chains coming back online, I expect some slowing of inflation. But we would need to be in the realm of about 2.3% (after base effects removed) inflation to see CPI below 3.1% in September.
Fed forecast is now 3.2%. They are likely being optimistic.

I just can't picture prices going down much over the summer, if at all, and they'd need to for us to end up in any other than the last bin. How likely is it that they could go down enough to see the 4th bin? @cafebedouin has done the math, and a sufficient drop over the time period left hasn't been seen in monthly FRED data. How far back did you look, @cafebedouin? Yes, these are unprecedented times, but an economy takes time to change course. I just can't picture all these economic dislocations resolving enough by September end up with a sufficiently lower CPI. And I bet it'll go up at least a bit over the summer, too. Food, household necessities, airfares, lumber, steel and aluminum prices, and, of course, anything with a chip in it.... The list goes on and on. Aluminum vendors have been giving price quotes that are valid for only 1 day, when 30-90 days used to be the norm. I'm sure it's the same for many things. In the long term, prices will likely fall back to bouncing around the long-term trend. But the long term won't be reached for a while, possibly up to 2 years for some things like computer chips and the items that require them. (Totally off topic, but I want to find some analyses and forecasts of long-term inflation that take into account climate change and its effects on everything from agriculture to migration. I suspect most long-term analyses that project low inflation over coming decades until demographic changes kick in are not factoring in effects of climate change.)
If CPI did not grow at all from now until September inflation % would be 3.23%
Prices have already risen over 3.1% compared with September 2020
Thanks to @DNK89. I went and rewrote an R script to go through the monthly FRED data, do percentages and it has never hit -0.13 for the remaining time we have left.

The 5 y Treasuries yield 0.774% at the time of writing.
https://www.cnbc.com/quotes/US5Y The 5-Year Treasury Inflation-Indexed Security, Constant Maturity (DFII5) has been falling until mid-May and seems to be reverting since then, gaining 0.2%
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFII5 This implies that
/the market expectation of mid-term inflation [US5Y minus US5YTIP] is narrowing again from its peak at almost 2.7% and 
/is currently at 2.444% This model does not exclude short-term jumps in inflation caused by volatile prices in single sectors, and it is probably not representative for the composition of the CPI. However, it may serve as a general indicator of inflation perception and trends threreof, and with a slight risk margin of 0.3% to 0.5% added on top of the implied inflation, the CPI would stabilize within the bounds of bin 4.

@cafebedouin
Longer term inflation trends are harder to predict and i would be inclined to your view on an equal weighted forecast if this were a longer term question (while i had a bias towards a higher long term inflation given the high fiscal and monetary response, it has somewhat been shaken a bit by how the Treasury bond has behaved recently) .  But this question only concerns the September CPI print which is just 4 months away. Given that we are already at 5% in May and the upper end of this question is (CPI of 3.1%), the price index would actually have to fall by more that 0.13%(from the May 21 print) to just drop below 3.1% mark
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPIAUCSL
(the CPI was 260.15 in Sept 20 and it is at 268.55 for May 21)

Just going with a random chance forecast because I believe the crowd is wrong. Current inflation is a short term surge, but then the question is how long it will do it and how long will it take to return to mean. I don't have a good sense of it.

OECD forecast is showing US inflation to stay high throughout 2021 and stabilize in Q2 2022. Q3 prediction is 3.72% and as @Ryan-Beck notes it would have to be below 0.0% moving forward to stay under 3.1% in Sept. https://data.oecd.org/price/inflation-forecast.htm The largest contributors to the increase seem poised to keep the current increases for at least the near term as well.
"Biggest price increases were recorded for gasoline (56.2%), used cars and trucks (29.7%), utility gas service (13.5%), transportation services (11.2%) and apparel (5.6%). Shelter costs were up 2.2% and food also went up 2.2%."  https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/inflation-cpi

New data: CPI is at 3.2% over last September. Used cars and trucks are going to continue to be scarce because new cars are scarce because chips are scarce, and at least some industry leaders have predicted that situation may last a couple years. I would doubt that airline fares are going to go down this summer, as airlines regain more of their customer base. And I would expect restaurant prices won't decrease, as demand for eating at restaurants goes back up. In short, I don't think it's likely that prices are going to go down much, if any, through September; I expect prices will increase at least somewhat through the summer and at most dip a little less than they increase through the end of September. So I think the last bin is most likely, but I'll still put a little bit of weight on the 4th bin just in case.
Please--at the rate at which the Fed is printing money and the government is spending it, we'll be fortunate if the rate stays on the low side of 4%.
CPI for May is 5%, but I don't know that it will continue to stay that high.

inching up but i'm still not super confident; inflation rates can fluctuate significantly month-to-month but the 15 month average of inflation, which encompasses the entire pandemic, is still very steady. i have no confidence that we are not looking at a temporary fluke that will peter out in the next month or so.

Average month over month inflation from here to September would have to be negative to stay under 3.1%. Not impossible due to the potential for recent price spikes to come back down and I would guess we might see a negative month or two, but very unlikely.
Today's numbers were above 5%.  Am adjusting bets accordingly.
Latest report is over 5%. That pulls the average up for the year. There are a number of inflationary pressures, as well as savings available for spending that could cause demand based inflation.
The non-annualized change in prices since Sept 1 is 3.2%. So you would need outright deflation over the summer (where prices tend to seasonally rise anyway). It's in the bag.
The "transitory inflation" narrative is a dangerous farce

Inflation will be higher than Fed expectations, but not so much above because just temporary factors are affecting inflation. There is more probability to go back to low levels of inflations. A lot of factors that have bring inflation high are due to COVID recuperation and it will ease after summer

Yellen remarks about higher interest rates are a "threat" against second-round-effects and free riders intending to raise prices based on a general inflation argument. "All items less food and energy" (April 2021: 3.0%) and "Services less energy services" ((April 2021:2.5%) are still way below average but have a significant weight.
The effect of Energy, "Gasoline, all types" in particular (April 2021:49.6%) is about to abate in May and June and is unlikely to hit its most recent all-time high of 54.8%/Sep 2005
"Electricity" in particular (April 2021: 3.6%) is likely to stagnate, since effects of higher production of renewables over the summer months and less demand pressure from domestic cryptomining (less rewards than between 08 Feb 2021 through 19 May 2021) or web-based streaming services will probably balance with higher air conditioning consumption.
"Commodities less food and energy commodities" (April 2021: 4.4%), which perfectly reflect the recent "All items" spike since February 2021, could have seen their peak for 2021 already in AprilMay, as is the case for lumber:
LSK20
3/31/2020: 278.50
4/30/2020: 319.70
LSN20
5/29/2020: 367.10
LSN21
3/31/2021: 888.90
4/30/2021: 1,376.50
5/28/2021: 1,309.50 (peak: 5/7/2021: 1,670.50, current as of 6/4/2021: 1,284.20) In all, solving the supply chain disruptions in the unexpected global and domestic pick-up of economic activity will be key to keep short-term inflation limited and reduce and normalize inflationary pressures before September 2021. The key sector, services less energy services, depends more on second-round-effects and scarcity of staffing (raised cost of staff) and gasoline cost (which will likely be a one-off and reverse) than on commodities or general inflation.
Re-ran Winter's method model and aggregated with selected peers.  Am upping my bet on the higher category now with some reservation.
I still think September is too short to see the major impacts of the predicted high inflation.

Coming down a bit. While it looks very unlikely that the index can grow slow enough to stay under 3.1%, there is a real chance that inflation could drop in the coming months as some of the temporary price increases subside. See the section at the end of this article on lumber for example: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/newsletters/2021-06-02/five-things-you-need-to-know-to-start-your-day?sref=vuYGislZ

You need an absolute price increase of 0.5% (not annualized) from April to September to get to 3.1%. When you look over the last 20 years, you tend to get very high seasonality in the summer 16 out of last 21 years have been able to meet that rate, and many of those years didn't have the broad based inflationary pressures we're seeing here so raising the outside forecast (80%) to roughly 90%.

Have been looking at some of the discussion points by colleagues such as @Scappleby and @alexandemeister.  I'm moderating my forecast down some based on the rationale that monthly high rates are unlikely to be sustained over time - ie, will regress down towards the mean.
I'm still not convinced the September rate will be as high as the crowd is expecting but have realized the odds of it being under 2.1 in a recovery year are very small so am shifting up accordingly.

Cleveland Fed nowcast showing CPI for may trending at 2.4% annualized rate, well above what it needs to get to 3.1% by September: https://www.clevelandfed.org/our-research/indicators-and-data/inflation-nowcasting.aspx
I'm still of the opinion that the current inflation rate is temporary and will stabilize as we head into the fall but there does seem to be more pressure than expected so I'm adjusting up

Adjusting upward to reflect the April 2021 rate of 4.2%, although we have already seen prices for certain commodities like lumber tick back down. I think the consensus on GJO is overconfident that inflation will continue to exceed 3.1% - we haven't seen sustained MoM inflation above that level since 2008, it is quite a rarity in the last 3 decades. I will forecast inflation to decline slightly in May relative to April....
Lots of commodity price pressure, as well as labor pressure.

Move from baseline central tendency has accelerated since prior forecast esp for some wage classes, and YoY effects from damped pandemic levels would amplify that acceleration Supply chain issues accelerating https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-05-17/inflation-rate-2021-and-shortages-companies-panic-buying-as-supplies-run-short?srnd=premium&sref=511OBpYh
Shortages and a lot of new money will lead to more inflation than 3.1%

We're at 2.57% now. And more companies will be raising prices this fall. Hard to see how it could stay under 2.7%; there would have to be no change or a decline, both of which don't seem likely at all. So I'll give that category a 0% chance. We have 5 more months to go. The CPI went up 0.77% just in the past month. If it goes up that much over the next entire 5 months, we'll be at 3.4%. It's easy to picture that happening right now.
No - I take it back. We're expecting inflation to be around 2% by the time September rolls around.
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/12/consumer-price-index-april-2021.html Looks like I badly misjudged this one!
Well the last reading seems to indicate that we might be close  of 5.5% by september than 4.5 %.
Adjusting probabilities higher after y'day very high headline and core CPI print for April.

This looks very likely after the April numbers. Here's a good thread from the White House Council of Economic advisors showing that some sectors had a strong spike in April but also that prices are still generally below pre-pandemic prices in some areas. To stay below 3.1% the average over the coming months would have to be pretty low. I'm not entirely ruling that out though, there are a lot of temporary things going on like a spike in lumber prices and a shortage of semiconductors and things like that. There are a lot of unknowns with the pandemic and reopening so it's possible some prices drop as things get back to normal. But overall it seems most likely that we see above average inflation which makes over 3.1% most likely. https://twitter.com/WhiteHouseCEA/status/1392484719212781571

M over m inflation only needs to average 0.15% over the next 4 months in order to hit the top bucket. It has averaged 0.35% over the last 12 months and averaged 0.52% this year. I expect the year over year inflation to jump up again next month (as we replace last year's -0.1%) and then level off. MAY 20  -0.1
JUN 20    0.6
JUL 20     0.6
AUG 20   0.4
SEP 20    0.2
OCT 20.  0.0
NOV 20.  0.2
DEC 20.   0.2
JAN 21     0.3
FEB 21    0.4
MAR 21   0.6
APR 21    0.8

April CPI YoY print is 4.2%, Core Inflation is 3.0%.
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/12/consumer-price-index-april-2021.html

Given the most recent print, you would need 0.3% annualized inflation to be below 2.7%. Not going to happen. You only need 1.2% to get to 3.1%. Baiscally you've already had 2.56% pricne increase since last Stepember, it's not going to be hard to get to 3.1!

This morning's release shows April CPI YOY rate at ~4.6%.  Fed has stated that inflation increases will be transient but hard to know what that means, per some articles this could be up to 2 years when compared to the GFC recovery peaks in commodities, etc.  Reran forecast using Winter's Method with new data and updated estimates.
Latest inflation report was over 4%. A bit high than I expected. Bumping estimates up.
I did a binning exercise where of group the 2020 and 2021 into the ranges suggested here. Then I calculated the probability that any one range hits.

Commodity prices skyrocketing, widespread reports of shortages, and employers unable to lure workers back until they raise wages. That plus strong demand from stimulus, fading pandemic risks, all set up for higher inflation. Main thing that could weigh it down is the goofy imputed rent calc in CPI.

The 05MAY2021 WSJ chart indicates that 'seasonally adjusted' CPI YoY through March 2021 was 2.64%. Revising my estimates because I don't think any numbers I was looking at previously were seasonally adjusted (which is a better way of forecasting a trend).
https://www.wsj.com/articles/everything-screams-inflation-11620163599

Mentions of ‘inflation’ in S&P500 quarterly filings have increased 800% over their previous 20-year maximum.
https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/bofa-transitory-hyper-inflation-ahead

The longer-term trend has been well below 2% for well-documented structural reasons. Current pressure from reinitiation of manufacturing activity, supply chain pressures, pent-up demand, unused consumer liquidity flowing into consumption, consumer relief optimism, wealth effects from stock market performance, and fiscal stimulus should be expected to wrench the trend up over the next several quarters.  That wrench move should begin to manifest by 3Q2021, and then  could continue to accelerate into 2022 Especially because the YoY comp will be against the pandemic 3Q2020 Quite a few people remain underemployed. They will feel the brunt of this trend, and their lower consumption could damp this pressure
With all of the money printing it's hard to see anything less.

1) Warren Buffett announced that Berkshire Hathaway is seeing 'very substantial inflation' on 30MAR21. 
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/03/warren-buffett-says-berkshire-hathaway-is-seeing-very-substantial-inflation-and-raising-prices.html 2) Zumper Rental Report says YoY National rental inflation is now 3.3% for 2 bedrooms and 2.2% for 1 Bedrooms.
https://www.zumper.com/blog/rental-price-data/ 3) Deblasio announces that NYC will reopen at 100% capacity on 01JUL21.

Shipping costs from China are skyrocketing. Lumber costs have increased 3x, home prices are up 12% nationwide. That said, CPI only measures rental prices (and not the price of homeownership; my rent is down 25% YoY) so it may be artificially pushed down. Paradoxically, the stimulus funds also appear to be inflating labor costs because people are paid more to sit at home than to work.
sharp increase from feb to mar (1.7 to 2.6%). Haven't hit 3% since Dec 2011, though we are certainly in unprecedented times thanks to the pandemic.
Shifting odds upwards towards the higher CPI numbers after recent data showed strong price pressures.
Projected ending April CPI using AR(2) model and then ETS forecast beyond.  Aggregated with prior 4Cast and sample of peers.

US economy is trying to come back. In certain areas, its already happened. In other areas, supply chains remain disrupted and trying to accommodate to new economic throughputs. Personally, grocery prices seem much higher. I read that wood prices have increased 400% over the last year (base product for houses as well as toilet paper). It "seems" overall prices are a lot higher, but how that translates into the official CPI All Items basket is different. I guess what I want to know is how focused will the Fed be to keep rates low if there is a larger surge to the CPI number? If they really believe an upsurge is more an artifact of restarting the economy, then policy should be to keep rates low while the economy adjusts to new supply chains, demands, etc. In any case, markets could get volatile towards the fall. Could there be a reset to a "new normal" closer to 2.5% while the economy restructures (and the restructure could be for a couple years).
The Summer spending spree has begun... early.

Given data since last fall, assumptions of monthly annualized growth rates for April on & the resulting 12-month % change: 
if 1% from April on, outcome exceeds 2.1%; if 1.8%, outcome exceeds 2.7%; if 2.6%, outcome exceeds 3.1% Given COVID vaccinations/lower caseloads, expect reopening to inspire consuming spending at higher than normal rates, especially given excess savings.  Supply chain could have issues keeping up, leading to add'l boost in inflation.  Assume that this combination leads to MoM annualized rates that peak above 2.6% in early summer but are not be sustained through the fall (though expect it to remain comfortably above 2% MoM ann. - hence 0% probability assumed for 2.1-2.7% 12-month change outcome).

Update. We've already passed 1.7% (260.280 in Sept. 2020, 264.877 in Mar. 2021; 1.77% so far), so that's out; I can't imagine prices going down unless some new, unexpected shock hits the US. If CPI stays close to long-term trend lines (e.g., 5-year, 10-year), then inflation would be ~2.1% to 2.4%. If CPI stays a bit below trends, then inflation could be ~2.05%, just barely inside bin 2. The analysts at the site below expect CPI to stay flat until around August and then slowly move upwards until a larger increase in early 2022. In that view, the current uptick is the result of short-term shocks, including the recent stimulus package. I can't picture any major new government spending initiative starting before Sept. 2021, either. But it's possible that food and/or energy prices could go up more than expected. I'm going to put weight on a bit more increases in costs than are forecasted below, but there's still so much economic damage to recover from that I can't picture inflation going much past 5-yr or 10-yr trends, if at all. Many seem to be forecasting high inflation based on a big spending boom, but with $1.3T transferred to the ultrawealthy in the past year and still so much to recover from, I'm not sure where all that increase in spending would be coming from. I suspect spending will shift and things will get better for a lot of people, but I don't see much inflation around the corner. In particular, I don't think the recent linear trend upward will continue much further.
https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/consumer-price-index-cpi

Housing starts at 2006 levels: https://www.reuters.com/business/us-housing-starts-increase-more-than-expected-march-2021-04-16/
Retail sales +9.8% Need about 2.6% annualized inflation from here to get to 3.1%. Need about 1.8% annualized inflation from here to get to 2.7%.

Major revision to my forecast. Hat tip to @erikbays whose comment made me rethink the numbers and run the index.
Simply the index in Sept 2020 was 260.280. In march 2021 the index is at 264.897. 
In 2020 from april thru december the index grew 1.6% which incljdes the negative growth in April and may 2020. 
So it is an easy projection to say the index will grow 1.6% from now to sept 2021. This puts the index at 269.115.
Then the year on year change for sept 21 is 3.4% ((Sept 21 - sept 20)/ sept 20). The data is from BLS and be sure to use non seasonal adjusted.

I did a little checking on the history data and the median 6 month increase in the index since 1996 is 2.4, which when added to March would get just over 2.7% in September. However it's likely the monthly increase in inflation over the coming months is above median. To hit 3.1% the rise in the index over the next 6 months would have to be about 40% higher than the median 6 month rise, which seems plausible. And worth noting that annual inflation over the next few months is probably going to be deceiving because there was a dip in the index a year ago, so need to be cautious on reading too much into annual inflation measures over the next few months. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1DgonPN1_pwKoNhMvCfY-qoBDDbPByZ-1wxur89UoTy4/edit?usp=sharing Also worth noting we appear to have returned to the rough trend since 2016 so while the stimulus probably still leaves higher than normal potential for inflation going forward, the "catch-up" effect may have been used up by now. Note that in this plot I just added a line between January 2016 and March 2021 data, it's not a true trendline. But I think it works as a rough trend over the last few years: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=D9Gy
Minor update expecting that there will be some regression to the mean effect
Adjust since inflation is 1.6% right now
Starting with base rates of @Terry-Smith https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1249343 Adjusting a bit to higher levels.
Adjusting a little towards the higher end based on today's March CPI release of 2.6%

I figured anything above 0.3% I would revise up, and we got 0.6%. Now at 2.6% year over year. If we just post zero the next two months we'll hit 3.5% y over y. By September 2021, mass vaccination efforts in the US will have begun to dramatically reduce both infections and deaths due to covid-19. The subsequent reopening of the American economy will kickstart the effects of the massive stimulus packages passed in 2020, whose influence on consumption has been greatly attenuated by the unprecedented lockdowns. With the reopening this dormant money supply will be suddenly unleashed, and if history is any indication, will produce a great inflationary pressure, with it's first effects beginning to be noticeable around this time. Note that this forecast is qualitative.

Negative Deficit/GDP Ratio combined with massive pent up spending and a much higher household savings rate. Reasoning is primarily qualitative. Feds continuing claims that inflation is only occurring in isolated areas that shouldn't actually count increases my confidence that they are looking to counteract emotional causes of inflation, lending credibility to the idea that they are very concerned with inflation but maintaining poker face.

This is my very first prediction so go easy on me!  I took data from here https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=CigL  thanks to @Ryan-Beck for the link I'm not sure if this is a good way to think about inflation but I did the following Since 1985
Average inflation was 2.566%
1 standard deviation up was 3.877%
1 standard deviation down was 1.255% In the past 68% of the monthly observations have been between 1.255% and 3.877%.  34% between 2.566% & 3.877% so I gave 2.7% - 3.1% the highest probability. Given the stimulus money I don't think we will see lower than average inflation so I bumped up the higher than 3.1% but I did leave some probability in the lower ends.
Ran an ETS forecast using the Monthly BOL data.  Then aggregated with peer team.

Seems like the move in Energy will skew things more to the upside than the crowd is seeing. 
Gasoline prices are up 25% or so since September: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=CUR2. Given the 7% weight of Energy in the CPI, implies something like a 1.4% contribution to CPI on its own. As a result, 2.1 and lower looks pretty unlikely, especially when you combine with massive fiscal stimulus and re-opening.
I think i was too high in the last bucket. Reducing but based kn sentiment nkt really any change in news.

Long-term downward pressures on inflation continue; effects of the pandemic and other influences are superimposed on that trend. OECD forecasts substantial Q2 rise and Q3 fall. Fed now predicts 2.4% PCE inflation for 2021, which is generally lower than CPI. Somewhere around 1.9% to 2.4% seems most likely to me for this forecast, straddling 2 forecast bins, of course. But, I don't rule out the possibility that it'll be below 1.7%.
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/17/heres-where-the-federal-reserve-sees-interest-rates-the-economy-and-inflation-going-in-the-future.html

One source forecasts 2.5%. Another said 1.7%. One month its above expectations, the next its below. Although growth should accelerate inflation seems to be charting the course which puts it in the 2% range, likely just below.

Again, the question involves "all items" which accounts for the most volatile items, e.g., food, energy. Health care and consumer shortages could also be significant drivers. [ A separate, but related question involves...what will the market reaction be to this higher CPI number? It seems markets are currently VERY sensitive to whiffs of inflation. So, can the Fed and others keep the waters calm (enough) to help markets accept a higher CPI (for an interim period). It seems a higher volatility could be on the mid-term horizon. And, is a bit higher inflation all that bad??, given the depressed economies of the last year. Don't we want the economies to expand? It will "never" follow a perfect line of expansion/retraction.]

The fed's market-based inflation probability indicates ~2.5% over the next 5 years, with a good (~30%) chance of exceeding 3%. https://www.minneapolisfed.org/banking/current-and-historical-market--based-probabilities This, however, for 5 years; as more people get vaccinated I expect some revenge spending and domestic travel to push up inflation in certain sectors drastically in the short term, which would impact the overall CPI. As this is all-items CPI, I also expect increasing oil prices due to travel resumption to be a significant factor.

Doing a bit of reevaluation because I did not know that the FED targets based on PCE inflation, which is a bit different and usually lower than the CPI inflation. Here's an info dump of what I found this morning. This tweet shows the market is giving 30% odds to CPI inflation above 3% over the next five years: https://twitter.com/MichaelRStrain/status/1374679943267946502?s=19 This tweet points out that's inline with about 2.5% PCE inflation: https://twitter.com/karlbykarlsmith/status/1374682881189109763?s=19 Digging around, I found a chart of the FED's median inflation projections over the next few years, in PCE inflation
 They expect 2.4% PCE inflation Q4 2020 to Q4 2021, and dropping to close to 2% inflation for 2022: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/PCECTPIMD According to that measure, the FED looks like it's using this PCE measure to judge inflation: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=CigI While the question here is using this CPI measure: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/graph/?g=CigL Here's a good article with information comparing CPI and PCE: https://www.clevelandfed.org/newsroom-and-events/publications/economic-trends/2014-economic-trends/et-20140417-pce-and-cpi-inflation-whats-the-difference.aspx Now that I have a little better idea of the different measures being used, there are some things I think worth noting. According to the first tweet, the market last gave 30% chance of CPI inflation over 3% over the next five years from about 2011 to 2013. Looking at the CPI chart, that never happened, inflation peaked briefly above 3% at the the of 2011 and then fell below 2% for the following years. So the market seems like it gets pretty easily spooked (although a 30% chance isn't too large, but it does seem higher than warranted giving the low inflation rates that followed). Next, just eyeballing the PCE and CPI charts, it looks like the PCE is generally about 0.5% lower than CPI, like Karl Smith suggested in the second tweet. So if we add 0.5% to the FED's median projection I linked to that would be 2.9% CPI inflation at the end of this year, and about 2.5% at the end of 2022. Putting all that together, I'm adjusting toward the higher buckets. My previous perception seems to have been biased downward by my incorrect understanding of inflation measures. I was translating the FED's projections and my perception of recent low interest rates straight to CPI with no adjustment, but I should have been adding about 0.5%. Now I'm putting the most weight on 2.7 to 3.1 based on the FED's estimate of 2.9% (2.4% PCE plus 0.5%) with second most on the highest bucket. Previously I was weighting the middle bucket the highest. Monthly annual inflation seems pretty noisy as well, so I'm keeping some probability in the lower buckets until we get closer to September and see what the inflation is looking like.
After a spike in april / may above 3%, I believe inflation will fall back slightly towards the second part of 2H21 but remain above the Fed's 2% target.

US by september would have almost certainly vaccinated 70% of the population that is needed for activity to return to pre covid scenario and we would then see an improvement in the velocity of money. CPI for February 2021 is at 1.7%. Between increased fiscal stimulus and reopening (increasing velocity of money), I expect a classic case of "too much money chasing too few/the same number of goods". The Fed expects 2.4% this year, and while I personally expect higher due to the aforementioned, I also expect politics to have a huge influence (it's in the best interests of the US government for inflation to appear on the lower end w.r.t. currency value, and interest rate on debt).

This is an interesting article about how the recent increase in the money supply has been largely offset by a decline in the velocity of money. the article is arguing against hyperinflation, but that doesn't mean we can't see high 2% or 3% inflation.
https://www.zerohedge.com/economics/hyperinflation-really-threat

I'm upping the odds of the higher end based on a couple tweets. One economist thinks it could get up to 4% this year. Tweet about higher inflation expectations: https://twitter.com/ModeledBehavior/status/1373271102705786880?s=19 Estimate of 4%: https://twitter.com/ModeledBehavior/status/1373275996862971908?s=19 I'm still keeping 2.1 to 2.7 a little higher because the FED still doesn't anticipate raising rates until 2023 and this is just the opinion of one economist. Worth noting the next few months through July will likely have higher inflation simply due to the dip in CPI during that period in 2020. February 2021 is already 2.8% higher than May of 2020, the lowest month of 2020. But August and September of 2020 had already risen back up to near where the trend would be. So the next few months will probably see inflation in the 3% range, but we should be cautious about interpreting that to mean it will exceed 3% in September. Here's the FRED series: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CPIAUCSL Tagging @erikbays and @SE_Meyer to note that I'm revising upward and to admit that I may have been underestimating the higher end. I think we still disagree on the longer term outlook but I appreciate our conversation the other day and it was influential in leading me to reevaluate my weights here so thanks for that.

Food and energy are usually excluded from the "usual" CPI calculation we hear most about in the news. With the volatility of F&E added for this question, it seems the All Items CPI will be more robust. ALso, airline pricing took a big hit in 2020, but should start to rebound over next several months. Businesses  still have a lot of PPE overhead that they have to accommodate into their operational costs and this is getting passed onto consumers. Many large businesses, e.g., Wal-Mart, McDonald's etc have been pushing up their wages which pushes consumer costs. And of course, the overall re-opening of the economy will be a significant factor/ The Fed seems willing to let the economy re-open and expand until it gets a stable footing. [As an aside, it will be interesting to see how accommodative the Fed will be for 2022. It seems like the WORLD economies will take awhile to get on their feet, i.e., longer than just 2021.]

Revising down, but will revise back up if the next few months are 0.3 or higher. Inflation needs to average 0.23% per month over the next 7 months to hit the 2.7% bucket. It needs to average 0.286% a month in order to hit the 3.1% bucket. The last eight months since June it has averaged 0.363% a month. Once we replace the March and April numbers year over year will jump up above 2.7% and everyone will change their predictions. But the Jun and Jul numbers are both 0.6 and we may not replace those with as high of a number and so that seems to be why Powell thinks the high inflation will not last. But if the trend of the last 8 months continues, and I think it will, we'll hit the 3.1 bucket. MAR 20 -0.4

We had -0.4 month over month in March 2020, -0.8% in April and -0.1% in May. as we replace these with positive numbers, or even if m over m inflation those months is just 0 we will be at 2.9%. If we see 0.1% those three months, we will break 3%.  Chairman Powell says the rise in inflation is going to be temporary. I disagree.  The market consensus for inflation this year is 3.3%. Previously the United States used to cover its debt by having foreigners invest. Japan, China, Russia, the EU, Saudi Arabia. in 2020 the Federal Reserve purchased more treasuries than were newly issued by the US Treasury. This means America covered its debts simply by printing money. this means instead of taking purchasing power from other countries, we have been straight up devaluing the currency. with all of these bailout packages we have been increasing deficit spending, and I expect 2021 to be a similar story where the Federal Reserve ends up having to purchase the lion's share of the treasuries. We are already seeing treasury rates climb in order to attract buyers. If treasury rates climb much more, the FED is going to have to step in and increase their purchases which to oversimplify it means more money printing. Another way to look at it is for every four shipping containers coming in full of goods, we are only sending out about one shipping container right now. And the shipments we are sending out are mostly raw materials, not finished goods. We are like a colony of China. We still have more people filing for unemployment every week than at the height of the great recession. We are purchasing these foreign goods with debt. That is not a strong economy, and does not bode well for the Dollar.

Average 12 month change = 2.09% , min = -2.1%(July 2009)  , max = 5.6%(July 2008) Average yearly range = 2.02 points , min = 0.8(2019) , max = 5.5(2008) Average Sept change = 2.03% , min = -1.3%(2009) , max = 4.9%(2008) Average change from Feb - Sept = 0.805 points , min = 0 (2015) , max = 1.8 (2011) (data [1]) Leading indicators... 
None of the individual components of the CPI seem to be 'ahead of the curve'. 
Gold is a historical hedge against inflation but I do not think its price is an accurate leading indicator either. Current situation... 
Before the pandemic, the velocity of money (frequency at which one unit of currency is used to purchase domestically produced goods and services within a given time period) was very low relative to the historical average [2]. Now, because of the pandemic, it is very very low and it directly influences inflation. 
There is (relative to history) a very high amount of private savings right now [3]. As the economy starts to open up, some of this money will be spent. 
The unemployment rate is relatively high resulting in lower than average spending but should continue gradually decrease, causing more spending. 
The $1.9tn stimulus package may start to influence inflation this year and there may be another huge spending package coming, focused on industry, again totaling more than $1 trillion. Other things...
Interest rate rise? Not likely this year due to Fed comments. 
More lockdowns if there are new variants? Possibly. [1]https://www.bls.gov/charts/consumer-price-index/consumer-price-index-by-category-line-chart.htm#
[2]https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/M2V
[3]https://www.statista.com/statistics/246268/personal-savings-rate-in-the-united-states-by-month/#:~:text=of%20the%20Treasury.-,The%20personal%20saving%20rate%20in%20the%20United%20States%20amounted%20to,trillion%20U.S.%20dollars%20in%202020.

My starting point for the calculation was the forecast of  @Terry-Smith  on the basis of its consistent rational. I think it is possible to add another data for more accuracy: the rate differential between February and September each year (because February is the closest data we have).
I calculated it by exporting the table available here : Over the last 10 years, the gap between February and September is -0.9 to 1.8. In 2021, the February rate is 1.7%. This gives us a rate of 0.8 to 3.5% for September.  This is not helpful since the proposals include these 2 values!

With the stimulus, upcoming boost from reopening, and the FED committing to let inflation run over 2% and aim for an average of 2% over time I think there's a decent chance inflation jumps up a bit this year before settling down. That's what Powell has said and it seems reasonable. Looking at the chart the highest inflation rate in the last 5 years is 2.9% in July 2019. So I'm keeping the chances of exceeding 3% as pretty low. But the series is also pretty noisy, so I think it's good to keep the probabilities spread out over the buckets within reason. It's also interesting that the middle bucket is over a range of 0.6% while the two adjacent cover 0.4%. Powell on an inflation bump in the short term: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/03/04/fed-chairman-powell-says-economic-reopening-could-cause-inflation-to-pick-up-temporarily.html Article on FED policy shift to average inflation targeting: https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/27/powell-announces-new-fed-approach-to-inflation-that-could-keep-rates-lower-for-longer.html
This is the base rate over the past 20 years, for September of each year. For example, in 2001 to 2020, 7 out of the 20 Septembers had CPI growth of less than 1.7%. And so on.

Ball-parking here. CPI over the last 12 months rose 1.7%. With the stimulus coming out I expect a bit of inflation I suspect not a dramatic amount, but I'm not an economist so I don't know how much "lag" there is on the CPI. Edit: https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/cpi.pdf Forgot to post my link
